Dear Ms. Marquess:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violation identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code License recommendation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12325
Section • (1) An agency shall recommend to the department the
Description appropriate licensing action consistent with facts contained
in the foster home evaluation and any special evaluations.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that the agency failed to make the appropriate
licensing recommendation based upon findings of special
evaluations.
Investigation The Licensing Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on
08/12/24. The Licensing Supervisor confirmed the agency had
conducted three investigations on the home of Foster Parents A
and B in 2023. The Licensing Supervisor reported the agency
recommended revocation of the foster home license at conclusion
of the third investigation. The Licensing Supervisor was asked
why the agency had not recommended revocation of the license
upon conclusion of the first and/or second investigation, each of
which the agency investigations had concluded that physical
abuse of a child had occurred in the home. The Licensing
Supervisor reported upon conclusion of the first investigation a
Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) Worker
involved in the case had recommended a corrective action plan
and supportive services to Foster Parents A and B. A safety plan
was also initiated.
The Licensing Supervisor reported upon conclusion of the second
investigation that Families First interventions were initiated for
Foster Parents A and B. The Supervisor also reported the second
investigation involved a different caregiver, in this case Foster
Parent B. The Licensing Supervisor reported the first investigation
involved Foster Parent A. The Licensing Supervisor reported since
each investigation involved different caregivers and children, they
were separate incidents of physical abuse and a recommendation
of revocation was not warranted. The Licensing Supervisor
reported the agency was looking for a pattern of abuse and the
different caregivers involved was not establishing a pattern. The
Licensing Supervisor reported the third investigation established a
pattern of physical abuse in the home and the agency therefore
recommended revocation of the license.
2

The Director of Children’s Services, hereafter referred to as
Director, was interviewed via telephone on 07/02/24 and
08/12/24. The Director reported the agency was following
recommended procedures contained in Communication Issuance
23-036 Updated, which recommends in part, that disciplinary
action or a corrective action plan is recommended when another
DHHS Worker has findings in a foster home.
The Director also reported that each of the first two investigations
involved different caretakers in the home and therefore there was
not an established pattern of abuse.
Staff 1, the agency Licensing Worker, was interviewed via
telephone on 08/13/24. Staff 1 reported that revocation of the
foster home license was not recommended upon conclusion of the
second investigation as a pattern was not established as the
physical abuse was committed by different caregivers. Staff 1
reported services were provided to the family as well as a
corrective action plan. Staff 1 reported the third incident of
physical abuse warranted a recommendation of revocation of the
license as the agency felt the third incident established a pattern
of abuse.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
• Special Evaluation #2023C0000507, initiated on 04/07/23,
established a violation of R 400.9201 as Foster Parent A
was found to have dragged a child as well as tapping
children on their heads and spraying children with water.
• Special Evaluation #2023C0000626, initiated on 05/15/23,
established a violation of R 400.9201 as Foster Parent B
had grabbed a child by the arm lifting the child off the
ground causing bruising.
• Communication Issuance (CI) 23-036 Updated was
reviewed. The CI states in part that if a confirmation by
DHHS Worker involves a licensed foster home the
Licensing Supervisor and licensing worker must implement
disciplinary action or a corrective action plan.
• FTM and included safety plan dated 04/25/23 was
reviewed. The safety plan involved additional training for
the foster parents as well as the foster parents increasing
self-awareness when feeling frustrated and removing
themselves from situations before their behavior escalates.
• The DHHS investigation reports were reviewed. Reports
were consistent with the special evaluations. All reports had
3

findings by the DHHS Worker’s as well as the agency’s
special evaluations.
Analysis The agency was found in non-compliance as two special
evaluations of the foster home established physical abuse
occurring in the home.
The Director of Children’s Services, Licensing Supervisor, and
Staff 1 had concluded that disciplinary action against the foster
home was not warranted after conclusion of the second special
evaluation as different caretakers were involved and a pattern was
not therefore established.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued
